In Edward's subsequent progress from the Border, to Edinburgh, Linlithgow, and Stirling, as detailed in the Itinerary, there occur no topographical obscurities. On Wednesday the 20th of June, he crossed the Forth (mer dâ€™Escosse) on the route to Perth, (Saint Jehan de Perte,) where he arrived on the following day, having rested at a place variously written in the manuscripts, (Outrear, Outreart, outreard.,) and pro- bably pronounced omre-ard, or rather Outre-arder3 under which disguise may be detected the name of Auchterarder, situated nearly mid way between Stirling and Perth.

Advancing onward, Edward crossed the Tay at the royal castle of Kinclevin Ï‚ (Kinclouen, Kynge Colomenâ€š) proceeded next day to the royal castle of Clony or Cluny, the extensive foundations of which may still be traced near the lake of that name Ï‚ and after remaining there for several days, he again set out on the ed of July, and rested at the royal castle of Inverqueich on the borders of Perthshire and Forfarshire, (Eutrekoic chastea) of which the ruins are still extant. From thence he proceeded to the Castle of For-far Í¾ to Fernwel, in the neighbourhood of Montrose, and to Montrose, (Mounros chastel et bonne ville,) where he sojourned from Saturday the 7th till Wed- nesday the 1 lth of July.
